claim: All mammals give birth to live young

supporting.text: Monotremes, such as the platypus and echidna, are mammals that lay eggs rather than giving birth to live young.

attacks.text: Monotremes, such as the platypus and echidna, are mammals that lay eggs rather than giving birth to live young.
Monotremes represent a very small and ancient exception, and the vast majority of mammals do give birth to live young.
The definition of mammals is based on multiple characteristics, not just reproduction, and monotremes still share other key mammalian traits like mammary glands.
Focusing on exceptions like monotremes distracts from the general rule that applies to over 99% of mammalian species.

supporting.text: The reproductive classification of mammals includes egg-laying species, which contradicts the claim that all mammals give birth to live young.

attacks.text: The reproductive classification of mammals includes egg-laying species, which contradicts the claim that all mammals give birth to live young.
Egg-laying mammals (monotremes) are extremely rare, representing only 5 species out of over 6,000 mammal species, making them exceptions rather than the rule.
The existence of even a single exception disproves a universal claim, regardless of rarity.
The definition of mammals is primarily based on mammary glands and hair, not reproductive methods, so the claim overgeneralizes.
Common biological definitions of mammals include viviparity as a key characteristic, making egg-laying species taxonomically exceptional.

supporting.text: Scientific consensus recognizes three subclasses of mammals, one of which (Monotremata) is exclusively egg-laying.

attacks.text: Scientific consensus recognizes three subclasses of mammals, one of which (Monotremata) is exclusively egg-laying.
Monotremes are a rare exception and do not represent the vast majority of mammals, which do give birth to live young.
The definition of mammals is based on shared characteristics like mammary glands, not solely on reproductive methods.
Even if monotremes are exceptions, the claim 'All mammals give birth to live young' is still incorrect due to their existence.

supporting.text: The presence of egg-laying mammals in the taxonomic order Monotremata demonstrates that not all mammals are viviparous.

attacks.text: The presence of egg-laying mammals in the taxonomic order Monotremata demonstrates that not all mammals are viviparous.
Monotremes are an extremely rare exception, representing only a few species, while the vast majority of mammals are viviparous.
The rarity of monotremes does not negate their existence, and exceptions disprove universal claims.
The definition of mammals traditionally emphasizes viviparity, and monotremes are often treated as evolutionary anomalies.
Modern taxonomy includes monotremes as mammals based on shared traits like mammary glands, regardless of reproductive method.
